positive.review: I was having a hectic period in life where I couldn't spare time for games, so I started looking for a game I could play for 5 minutes each break. At the 5-minute break during an extensive work session, I click the banana with a left- and right-click combo, release my energy, sometimes get bonuses, and then return to work. The game also has so many skins, most of which are very cheap, so you can keep switching them as you want a new look. Builders, the Well of the Past, the exchange system, and collecting and trading banana skins are parts of the game that take the fun to the next level. Totally recommended!ü™Ω

Banana is a strangely addictive little clicker that‚Äôs perfect for quick sessions and background grinding. It‚Äôs not deep, but it delivers exactly what it promises: silly, low-effort fun with a surprisingly active community.

Pros:

    Simple, instantly understandable gameplay.

    Colorful, goofy visuals that stand out in your library.

    Collecting and trading different bananas is oddly satisfying.

    Great as a background game while doing other stuff.

Cons:

    Extremely repetitive after a while.

    No real depth, story, or challenge.

A simple clicker game that is strangely fun to play. You just click a banana and watch numbers go up. The best part is you can get free sellable items like cards and bananas that can be traded or sold on Steam. It is silly but relaxing and easy to enjoy while doing other things.
Banana is a very simple clicker game, but that simplicity is exactly what makes it charming. It‚Äôs easy to understand, light-hearted, and offers quick moments of fun. <3 <3

Banana is a free clicker game where you‚Ä¶ click a banana. Sometimes.
That‚Äôs it. That‚Äôs the game.

You open it, stare at a single JPEG of a banana on a green background, get an achievement for existing, and then leave it running so Steam can occasionally drop banana stickers into your inventory like financial jump scares.

---

### Gameplay (lol)

* Click banana ‚Üí number go up
* Leave game open ‚Üí every **3 hours** get a common banana item
* After enough playtime, unlock a rarer drop every **18 hours**
* List banana on Steam Market for 3 cents and hope someone buys your digital potassium

There are ‚Äúrarities‚Äù like:

* Normal
* Common
* Uncommon
* Rare
* Epic
* Ultra Rare (1 in 400,000)
* Legendary (1 in 10,000,000) ‚Äì a few even sold for over **$1,000** because reality is broken.

---

### Pros

* Free. Literally costs nothing but your dignity.
* Lowest system requirements of all time:

  * OS: Yes
  * GPU: Can it display yellow? You‚Äôre in.
* You can ‚Äúplay‚Äù while doing literally anything else. Work, school, sleep, other games‚ÄîBanana is your weird little side hustle in the taskbar.
* Steam profile flex: ‚ÄúYeah bro, my rarest item? A PNG of a fruit.‚Äù

---

### Cons

* It‚Äôs not really a game, it‚Äôs an **economy with a banana attached**. The clicking does nothing except give your finger a sense of purpose.
* You will start saying things like ‚ÄúI‚Äôm investing in bananas‚Äù out loud and people will worry.
* Steam Market prices swing harder than your motivation; your ultra-rare might be worth rent one day and bus fare the next.
* Spawns endless clones: Cats, Car, Broccoli, Poop, etc. The Fruitpocalypse is real.

---

### Peak Banana Moments

* Booting the game for the first time and realizing there is **no menu**, **no options**, just fruit.
* Getting your first rare banana and feeling prouder than any actual in-game achievement you‚Äôve ever earned.
* Tab-checking your inventory at work like a stock trader: ‚ÄúDid my JPEG banana moon yet?‚Äù
* Reading angry forum threads about how this is ‚Äúruining Steam‚Äù while happily claiming your 3-hour common peel.

---

**7/10**
As a video game? 1/10.
As a social experiment / Steam Market casino wrapped around a fruit? 10/10.

Would once again launch Banana, click it twice, minimize it for three weeks, and call that ‚Äúplaying‚Äù again.

I honestly don‚Äôt know how Banana manages to waste this much of a player‚Äôs time while offering absolutely nothing in return. The ‚Äúgame‚Äù is literally just a static picture of a banana that you click. That‚Äôs it. No sound effects, no animations, no upgrades, no variety, no effort. It feels like someone tested a button on their screen, forgot to remove it, and decided to upload it to Steam as a joke. Except it‚Äôs not even a funny joke‚Äîit‚Äôs just lazy.
What really pushed me over the edge was realizing how painfully slow and unrewarding the skin system is. You barely get any skins at all, and when you finally do, they‚Äôre almost always the most basic, common garbage you‚Äôve already seen a hundred times. It takes days‚Äîactual days‚Äîjust to get an uncommon skin. Not rare, not epic, not legendary. Uncommon. And even then, the skin doesn‚Äôt do anything. It doesn‚Äôt make clicking feel better, it doesn‚Äôt add new mechanics, and it doesn‚Äôt enhance the game in any meaningful way. It‚Äôs just another picture slapped on the same lifeless banana.
The insane part is that the game tries to make these skins feel special by making them so ridiculously hard to get, but all it really does is highlight how empty the entire experience is. There‚Äôs no excitement when you unlock one‚Äîonly relief that your time-wasting grind finally spat out something slightly different than the usual common skins. And after that brief moment, you‚Äôre right back to clicking the same dead screen, wondering how a game this empty convinced you to keep playing for so long.
The store page acts like Banana is quirky or weird in a fun way, but that‚Äôs misleading. There‚Äôs no twist, no charm, no hidden joke. It‚Äôs not satire. It‚Äôs not commentary. It‚Äôs not some clever minimalist experiment. It‚Äôs just an empty, thoughtless concept stretched into something that pretends to be engaging when it‚Äôs really nothing but a monotonous loop of clicking and disappointment.
The more I played, the more obvious it became that there‚Äôs no real point to anything you do here. You‚Äôre not progressing. You‚Äôre not discovering anything. You‚Äôre not improving your character or your experience. You‚Äôre not even building toward a joke payoff. There‚Äôs absolutely no reason to keep playing besides hoping that maybe, just maybe, the next click will finally deliver something worth the time. But it never does.
I don‚Äôt mind simple games, and I don‚Äôt mind joke games either, but Banana doesn‚Äôt function as either. It‚Äôs too empty to be enjoyable and too slow to be funny. The skin system feels designed to drag out your time, the core gameplay is nonexistent, and the whole thing ends up feeling like a parody of what a parody game even is.
If you‚Äôre looking for something entertaining or unique or even mildly distracting, don‚Äôt bother with Banana. This isn‚Äôt a game‚Äîit‚Äôs a time sink that gives nothing back. You‚Äôll get more value, enjoyment, and meaning from staring at an actual banana sitting on your counter, because at least that banana won‚Äôt waste your time pretending to be something it isn‚Äôt.  SO DONT PLAY!

It's easy for achievements yes, but the drop rate is too slow. To achieve all of them, you must buy bananas in the market of the same kind to make an exchange. As for the clicking of the game, the boost help a lot. After a a dozen hours you could achieve the billion clicks. As for auto clickers, the game doesn't mind, however, the max is 20 cps. With the boost it's basically unlimited depending on how many you add. There's no point in clicks after the 1 billion. Thereafter the game is running idol to get a varity of bananas dropped in which you could, therotically sell in the market for a penny. The market is flooded with bananas so good luck selling them. You'll be paying more in electricity than you'll get on this game. To sum it up. To get all the achievements you'll need to spend about 12 hours & $3 to platinum this game. Do I recommend? No. It's a waste of time & resources.
